characters: WE HAVE NO FUCKING IDEA WHERE WE
A WARM QUEBEC WELCOME TO THE ASSOCIATION OF FICTO-CRITICA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGGIE: We see the back of her blonde head. It’s a beauti winter day. Now we see her from across the street. We see feet making determined strides. This is a young woman who knows where she is going. Wide shot: A blind man is tentatively making ready to cro the street. Among the handful of pedestrians about to cross, Maggie i the only one to notice, and helps the man across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY, Maggie’s best friend, looks a little like Art Garfu as a young man: fluffy hair, glasses, dressed in a suit jacket and baggy chinos. He’s pushing a stroller with a reading, fluffy-haired, bespectacled four year old boy in wearing a t-shirt with “IMAGINE THERE’S NO FRACKING” writ on the front. This boy is too big to be in a stroller, an too young to be reading. Maggie rushes to them.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sorry! Sorry I’m late... Hi! Hi Max! She snuffles the little boy’s neck.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You still have one little corner of baby smell. Right (sniff) there. Max giggles and pushes her away so he can get back to his reading. Maggie straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ach, I need a baby! She bites her fist.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You need a baby? You’re such an impatient little fuss-budget.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I just don’t see why I should wait.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: For a father, perhaps? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Let’s face it. I’ve never been in a serious relationship that lasted longer than six months.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (paying) We were together for two years. They walk.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: In college. And we made each other miserable for the rest of the time.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I admit it. We were miserable. But we were also happy.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. They reach a stand of homemade jams. Tony picks one up.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Just so you know. I have little sperm tucked away in a facility uptown, if you’re in a pinch.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What?! Why? I thought Felicia didn’t want any more kids.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Felicia does not want any more kids. I froze it in case I ever meet anybody nice.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I didn’t. But I might, you know, save it, like ‘mad money’-style? Maggie has something to tell Tony, and she wants to get i over with fast.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (rushing this part) Do you remember Guy Childers, from college? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment as Tony searches for the name in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Wasn’t he the Guy...he’s a pickle salesman?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He’s a pickle entrepreneur. And-- he’s agreed to make a donation, so I can inseminate myself.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: But he has no sense of personal space!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: So what? He was a math major. Anyway, I’m not marrying him, I’m borrowing his genes.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: But not his personality I hope. Guy Childers...?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Everybody has something a little wrong with them. You think everybody's honest who fills out those questionnaires at the sperm bank?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you've been cooking this up all this time and you didn’t even tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I knew that you’d yell at me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m not yelling at you! Isn’t this sort of thing for women who are like forty-nine and desperate?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want it to be a last resort, I want it to be a choice. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because I’m ready be a mother, and I don’t believe I’1l find a man who I can stay in love with-- or who can stay in love with me-- for more than six months. I’m just facing the truth about myself. Tony is morose at this news, but he accepts it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So when’s the insemination? Are we gonna have a party?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: In four months. As they walk away from camera:

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Do I have bad breath? He breaths into the air near her mouth. She sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No. Do I? She breathes into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No. And they walk off. Good friends; unusual friends... INT. GUY CHILDERS’ BROOKLYN PICKLE FACTORY - DAY 8 Hipsters in hats and Mexican technicians are creating pic in huge vats. GUY is walking Maggie through aisle after a of pickles. Guy is wearing a Peruvian hat with flaps, sho and clogs.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I started production in my apartment three years ago. Now I have twelve employees, and I just got an order from Whole Foods. If that works out we’re taking off. But I’m still very hands on. Every pickle has my stamp of approval on it. He withdraws a pickle from a vat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, try this one.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I love this!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: That’s the Bavarian. Classic.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: This is the best pickle I’ve ever had. Guy looks at her, beaming. Jump cut:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy and Maggie are at the front desk of Brooklyn Brine. G takes off his gloves as Maggie notices a pair of hockey skates hanging from a coat stand.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You skate?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Every Sunday. I grew up on the ice.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh right. You were on the ice hockey team.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I used to skate a lot when I was little. A moment of awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: So, regarding our plan. Here... is my bill of health. With an air of pride, he spreads his blood test results across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Read it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (scanning the results) That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh! I have for you: Maggie takes an empty plastic specimen jar out of her pur

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Ah. He takes it and looks into it, as if for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You need to keep it warm, when you...so just put it next to your body underneath your shirt...and you can come right over.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Okay... Guy places the jar on the desk. They look at it together.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So when do you want to do this?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: March...twenty third? Guy thinks about his schedule. No conflicts come to mind.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just want to build up some more savings. Guy pulls out a stool for Maggie solicitously, in anticipation, perhaps, of her pregnancy.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: That’s smart.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I have insurance and everything. So, I guess the question is, how much involvement do you want? I was going to suggest none, but I’m open to negotiation. A beat as Guy digests this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: None is...so cool. It kind of takes the pressure off, doesn’t it? He takes a seat and leans back against the refrigerator, beside a large circulating fan.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can just relax, and build my empire. The fan blows Guy’s STD bloodtest result paper across his desk; they both move to stop it, and their fingers touch. INT. MAGGIE’S BUILDING - DAY 3 Close up of a mailbox being opened with a key. Maggie draws out two identical white envelopes. Puzzled, opens one, then the other. EXT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - DAY A3 Maggie walks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie enters the big glass doors. INT. NEW SCHOOL - BURSAR’S OFFICE - DAY 5 A large woman with close-cropped hair and a neck brace si behind the desk with the air of a sage.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hi Beverly. I got two checks this month. Not that I’m complaining.

dialogues.speaker: BEVERLY
dialogues.text: You sure they’re not for two different payments?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I would love to think that... but they have the same date on them and I was paid last month.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Excuse me... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera pans right to include a shambolic, sleep-depri edgy man.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I couldn't help but overhear this young woman got two checks. And I don’t have any. Beverly looks up at him, displeased at this complication.

dialogues.speaker: BEVERLY
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: John Harding.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh well my name is Johanna Hardin, I mean my name is Maggie... but on the check it’s Johanna Margaret Hardin. So maybe there was a mix- up. Beverly is on the computer. She looks a little put out. S hates this kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: BEVERLY
dialogues.text: Yep. And it’s gonna take a minute to figure this out.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It would be great if it could be resolved soon. Beverly looks up at him with her final answer.

dialogues.speaker: BEVERLY
dialogues.text: We'll get back to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and John walk down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Damn. That woman could guard hell, if Cerberus ever needs to go to the vet.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Everyone’s scared of Beverly. What do you teach? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ficto-critical Perspectives in Family Dynamics, and Masks in the Modern Family, Victorian Times to the present day.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Psychology department?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Anthropology.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (scrutinizing him) I don’t know any anthropologists.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m the Director of Business Development and Outreach for the art and design students.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I help graduate students strategize for success in the art and design world. Sort of a bridge between art and commerce. I help them sell their souls. And eat.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Are you old enough to do that job?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I have a master’s degree in arts management. They exit frame as the camera, with a will of its own, pa down to look through the glass wall at the courtyard belo and a round metal bench with a phallic center.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (os) Good to know. See you later.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (os) Good luck with getting paid!  10 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several days later, Maggie is in line with FELICIA, Tony' wife. Felicia is wearing a t-shirt with “What would Jesus Buy?” Written on it. She and Felicia are mid-conversation when John calls out. The camera pans over to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Felicia -- when is that -- that Pike fellowship meeting?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: Thursday at seven.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (sighing) Great, thanks. The women sit.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s so funny that you know John Harding.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: (eating her soup) We're on a committee together. He’s a real panty melter. Why?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, we just -- had a check mix-up recently -- because of our names-- Hardin/Harding.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: He’s one of the bad-boys of Ficto- critical Anthropology. Apparently, he was a big deal in Chicago. And now he just does adjunct work here, but they’re really salivating for him to teach full-time.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Why won’t he?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think it has something to do with his wife. She’s some kind of monster apparently.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Where did you hear this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Around. She’s got tenure at Columbia. Georgette Nergaard. The words ‘Glacial’ and ‘Terrifying’ have been bandied about. Then again I've heard myself described as a psychotic bitch, but I think I’m actually pretty nice, so... you can’t believe everything you hear. Maggie is distracted by John’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: -if you say ‘she was, like, terrified’, it’s nothing compared to saying’ she was terrified’. "Like” is a language condom. Trust me. Maggie looks back at John, now a far more mysterious character.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: (searching in her salad) Where the fuck is my chicken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is nursing a coffee, sitting on a bench, reading the paper, when he notices Maggie, who is circling the founta with vigorous, calisthenic strides. He watches her circle couple times. Calls out:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, Hardin?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, hi!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm taking a little constitutional before my next meeting. John gets up and walks over to her.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you get paid yet? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Beverly tells me the check is coming any day now. 12. 11 Maggie and John walk past a man in a fancy suit kneeling scoop up his dog’s turd.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I knew this Masai from Tanzania. He was here to run in the Marathon. He took everything in New York City in complete stride. Nothing fazed him until he saw a grown man following his dog, picking up its shit. He started laughing so hard, he wept.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I guess that-- custom-- would be strange, like, out of context. Whoops!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I overheard part of your conversation. About ‘like’ being a - - language prophylactic. He’s trying to remember saying that.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is ficto-critical anthropology, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s a way of writing about anthropology that blends ethnographic observation, story telling and, like, theory. A beat. Two smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do we have to walk in a circle, or are we allowed walk around the park?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We're allowed. They begin to meander.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (curious about him) It’s so hard to find a full-time position.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: When my wife, Georgette, was offered a tenured position at Columbia, I decided to put off a job search, just teach a few classes and finally try to write this novel I’ve had in my head for years. They pass two bomb squad-looking men sharing a joke. They walk

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (intrigued) So, are you getting a lot of work done, on your novel?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: They say every relationship has a gardener, and a rose. Georgette is definitely the rose.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: And you’re the gardener.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: And I don’t have a green thumb.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Maybe you’re a rose in disguise.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It would be a very good disguise. along for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's wonderful. It’s just she’s kind of destroying my life. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maggie isn’t sure how to respond to this remark, dropped kind of aside as John ambles along.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, no. It’s just been a bad week. (looking up at the sky) It’s turning into a beautiful day. They come to a man performing Shakespearean soliloquies f donations.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Content with Hermia? No! I do repent/The tedious minutes I with her have spent. Not Hermia, but Helena I love./Who would not change a raven for a dove? John gives him a dollar. ACTOR (CONT’D) Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later. They have cupcakes and are sitting o the same bench John was on earlier. They are mid- conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We have two of those. Best part of my life. Who’s your guy?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No guy. Actually, the man I’ve asked to be the father is named Guy, coincidentally. John tears a bite off.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughing) You eat like Mr. Fox!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: There was a Roald Dahl book? And then it was a movie--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. My kids loved that movie. Maggie looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really like what you're doing, though--having a baby by yourself. Not that it won’t be hard, because it’s gonna be fucking hard. But, I admire your courage. And I love babies.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I just don’t like leaving my destiny...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: To destiny?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Right. The Shakespearean actor from the park walks by them, stil his ruff. He is with another man who is silent, furious.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: (tearful) But where will I go? The other man shrugs. The Actor runs after his lover. ACTOR (CONT’D) You can’t just kick me out of our house...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to Maggie) I have a question for you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Would you consider reading a chapter of my novel?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I know that’s weird. I really want the first reader to be like...You know how you said you're a bridge between art and commerce? Well, I need a bridge.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Perfect. Give it to me. I’ll read it. John reaches into his backpack and pulls out about fifty pages of a novel.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You really will? I really would appreciate it. Maggie takes it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t mind at all. She looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta go. Shoot. John looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (panicked) Oh shit! Shit! Shit! I gotta go. I gotta go!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh-- He grabs his bag and runs off.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’1ll see you later. Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (baffled, calling after him) Okay, Bye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John rushes to the wings and into a big close up as he lo out at the stage with trepidation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: KLIEGLER
dialogues.text: (os) What do you make of the use of masks in the Occupy movement? High shot: see John stride onto the stage. GEORGETTE, Joh beautiful Danish wife, and a moderator, KLIEGLER, have started this panel on MASKS IN POLITICS without him. His is rudely empty. As John does his walk of shame across th stage, Georgette speaks in a clipped Danish accent.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: The masked revolutionary is a direct inversion of the face of the demagogue-- the essentially fascist ideal of the magnetic individual... As John passes, Georgette gives him an extremely dirty lo Laughter, laughing. Applause.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (into the mic) Sorry I’m late. because he’s so damn charismatic. Georgette isn’t

dialogues.speaker: KLIEGLER
dialogues.text: (holding up John’s book) John Harding, author of many books, most recently, “Rituals of Commodity Fetishism at the Tail End of the Empire”. He’s popular.

dialogues.speaker: KLIEGLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So John, of course we have been discussing the Occupy movement--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I can’t help mentioning the irony that Warner Brothers owns the copyright on the V for Vendetta mask that became the face of the Occupy movement. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Applause. 18.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Like it or not, in this country, the most potent, totemic symbols are cinematic or television-based; so it only makes sense that a radical, popular movement would try to subvert them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, the reality of Occupy is to be found within the capitalist narrative, as a kind of subplot.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: This sweeping cynicism of yours--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: If by sweeping cynicism you mean not living in a dream, then shoot me now.

dialogues.speaker: KLIEGLER
dialogues.text: Maybe the way we--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nobody ever thinks a revolution is going to happen until three days after it’s happened. This was a leaderless movement. It wasn’t going to happen on a schedule. This was a genuine populist uprising.

dialogues.speaker: KLIEGLER
dialogues.text: Yes! Because-—

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Absolutely. But to return to the use of masks in politics. I am more interested in the possibility of anonymity and group affiliation -- the “I am Spartacus” maneuver -- which has been the primary tactical explanation of the use of masks among various 20th and 21st century protest movements. Including the Zapatistas, the black blocs of the anti-globalization movement, and, of course, Pussy Riot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As her speech wears on, we see John wilting like a daisy sauna. He radiates resentment and defeat.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 15
dialogues.text: INT. JOHN AND GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT - EVENING 16 Close up of Georgette’s manicured hand, texting. We go wi to reveal a family dinner. John is standing, serving Georgette pasta.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You don’t need to help, but could you please put that down?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (texting) One moment. She puts the phone down. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) Okay. John sits. JUSTINE, 13, in a school uniform, sits beside dreamy brother, PAUL, 7.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: I don’t get why you say the same thing in the concluding paragraph as you do in the opening paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You're repeating your thesis but in a more developed form.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: What’s the point of that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: By the time you get to the conclusion you’ve proven your thesis.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: So it’s basically just gloating.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (amused) It is a form of gloating, yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (To John: ) They have fleas in Paul’s class again.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: They don’t have fleas. They have lice.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Okay, lice.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to Paul) Let me check your head. Paul walks over to John. John checks his head.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have lice. Georgette catches Justine texting.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: No texting at the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I wonder where she gets it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I use my phone for work.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sometimes I’d like to smash it with a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Ha-ha. Georgette’s phone rings. She is dying to answer. The kids both watch their mother restrain herself as John fumes. T phone rings out as Justine speaks.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: Way to go Mom.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Salad? As Georgette serves, her phone pings: a text! She glances the text and sucks in air, shocked. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (flushed with excitement) They've asked me to chair the department at Columbia!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Congratulations. That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: It'd be a huge time commitment.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Still, it’s a high-class problem.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: When will I ever get my writing done? I’ve promised to deliver that book by December. Georgette checks her reddening breast bone. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) Come on. You'll get a big bump in salary-- GEORGETTE (CONT’D) Look -- I’m already breaking out in a rash!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’ve got an idea. Why don’t you call Caleb back and discuss it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I have to.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Justine, you want to text your friend. Justine nods, mystified by this change in policy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paul, you want to play Ninja Revinja on your iPad? Go. 21. 16 Paul jumps up to get the iPad. John pulls out a flip phon (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I myself even have a minor text I would like to respond to. We can skip the pretence of having a close- knit family dinner. (looking down at his phone) And we can return to the bullshit later. Justine texts. Georgette is on the phone. Close on his te from Maggie: “finished the first chapter!”

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (os) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on John’s manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The tone is so unusual - sort of screwball-surreal. Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That sounds right. Screwball- surreal. That’s it exactly! They are both freezing, huddled on their bench.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: And oh my God the characters! Martin Neems the colorless postal worker in 1950’s Connecticut and he’s married to this crazy Brazilian woman who keeps breaking out in rashes! It’s hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (drinking in her praise) Really? Really?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, and the description of the musical collection!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, his records you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Oh, that is so great. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s funny, right?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s great. I’m sorry. I am very, very cold. I feel like I’m welded to the bench. Is it okay if we go get some coffee? The camera moves left, to a westward path, as if it knows what’s going to happen next. MAGGIE (CONT’D) (os) Actually, my apartment is like three blocks from here. I just need to get another sweater. I’m deathly cold. They walk into shot and walk down the path through the fr wind.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I cannot tell you how much I appreciate you doing this.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh it was so much fun to read.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Really? Did you think the boil was gross or funny?

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 18
dialogues.text: INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - AFTERNOON 19 Maggie and John enter, gasping with cold. The tiny living room is absolutely crammed with books.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I sublet from a poet. John looks around him at this charming apartment.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want some tea? Or...I guess that’s his wine, or...I have whiskey. It’s a little early. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We could make a hot whiskey. Do you have some honey and lemon? Maggie looks into the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I have half a lemon. And... honey.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I‘1l make it for you. Maggie walks to her closet and puts away her coat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay, great.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (os) You're clearly a reader.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Actually most of these books are his. Maggie looks in the mirror for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - AFTERNOON 20 Close on a pair of glass mugs filled with hot whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hot whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. She takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh it’s so good. Medium wide: they sit in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So. Tell me. I’m curious about you. Maggie looks up at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He stands, 25. 20

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What about me? What aspect of me?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Every aspect.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know where to start.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How about the beginning? takes off his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m hot.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I know. John sits down again.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (drinks) Well, I had a... kind of unusual start.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: wee?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: My parents were married fairly young and they never had kids. They were academics at the University of Wisconsin. Then eventually they got divorced, my Dad moved away... but then later, years later, they ran into each other at a party. And they... they got together that night. And that’s how I was conceived. On the bed with all the coats. My mom always says that it’s because I needed to be born.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I love that idea. That our unborn children are the real gods, dictating the fates of us poor, clueless mortals. Did they...they got together after that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Saying it Maggie is 26.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No. My mother raised me on her own in Madison. She was a professor of nineteenth century British poetry. She wasn't very practical. So I ended up doing all the day-to-day stuff. I was organizing the bills by the time I was twelve. She came from a Quaker family... so she used to take me to Quaker meetings with her. I still go, sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: A Quaker.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We had a nice life. And then when I was sixteen, she died. still shocks Maggie, and tears glimmer in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (matter of fact) So I moved in with my Dad in Philly. surprised to feel that she’s crying.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How was that?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Um... cordial. And quiet.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sounds lonely.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. He finds her so touching.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I grew up in a house... where nobody ever stopped yelling at each other.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (recovering, laughing) Heaven! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A moment. He stands 27.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (trying to be positive) My dad is a kind man. And he made the best of it. We both did. The atmosphere has changed.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what about you? Tell me about you. Background-wise.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: My father worked at a blackjack table in Atlantic City. But it’s a really long story. And I have to get back to my dysfunction. back up. Puts on his coat. Looks down at her sitting on the couch. He rushes

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That you had to be born. out the door. As it shuts, the ‘reading, writing, falling in love’ montage (improvised dialogue) begins: INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - DAY Maggie reads John’s book. This image is intercut with:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: & GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT - DAY OR NIGHT B22 John writing at his dining room table. (We hear his voice over the montage.)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Martin Neem dreamed the same thing every night, but he could never remember what it was. His wife, Talia, slept like a stone. Talia was a small woman. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A small, beautiful woman with hair like a river of snakes and the temper of an angry mink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is walking away from us; Maggie toward us. They meet the middle of the hallway, greet each other, then John tu and goes off with Maggie, toward camera. He can’t resist talking about the new chapter she just read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie skating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Maggie discuss his book on their bench in Washin Square Park, eating dosai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New School courtyard (seen from above on the round bench saw earlier): Maggie and John, still talking about the te

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Do you think this is overwritten?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (OS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think John’s book is a novella. INT. FELICIA AND TONY’S APARTMENT - DAY C22 Maggie, looking a little tired, but lovely in a tweed ski and sweater, is eating a carrot as Tony tries to assemble piece of IKEA furniture.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s short and very strange. It might even be an allegory. I like everything I’ve read. He’s asking me for suggestions.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh? What does his wife think about that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She doesn’t know about it. To be honest, I don’t think she pays much attention to what he does. She’s very self-absorbed. She might even be a narcissist.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Of course she is.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Why of course? He’s basically a psychiatric nurse. He can’t write his novel under those conditions -- I think their marriage fell apart after the second child was born. And now he’s trapped in it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That's what he’s telling you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Why would he lie?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: To get in your pants! INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - LATE AFTERNOON 24 It’s March twenty-third. Guy is taking off his jacket. Ma looks to see if the pockets are bulging. He reaches into large pocket and produces a small, mashed bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh! Thank you. She puts the flowers in a glass, then turns expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you... bring it?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh! Fuck... I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's why I gave you the little... container?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Where’s your bathroom? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Um... Guy looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: So what do I deposit my genetic gold mine into? Maggie rushes over to her cupboard and takes out a little plastic jar like the first one she gave him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (handing it to him) It’s sterile. Guy holds it between his thumb and forefinger. He takes a step to the bathroom, then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Listen. I feel it behooves me, to, ah, offer to do this the old fashioned way. Given the extreme state of your beauty and my totally free afternoon. A moment as the absolute awkwardness of this offer sinks

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No...no thank you, Guy. I just think that would be too complicated.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: No sweat, just being polite.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Should I go out for a while?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Nah, just read something. I'll be back in a jiff with the jizz. He marches to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Guy?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Hm? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you end up becoming a mathematician?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I liked math because it was beautiful, that’s all. I never wanted to be a mathematician.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (encouraged) Really? You think math is beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I don’t think. I know. Anyone who has touched even a hem of that garment knows it’s beautiful. For me, the hem was enough. I couldn’t have taken the frustration.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Of never seeing the whole thing. Of always just getting little glimpses of the whole picture. Spending my whole life hunting for scraps of truth. Embarrassed by his own candor, Guy turns and shuts the do to the bathroom, leaving Maggie bemused and oddly charmed this unique character. Hearing the water run in the bathr she turns some Ska music up high on the iPod as a sound buffer. She is so happy, she does a solitary dance. After few beats, Guy appears with the plastic jar Maggie gave h a little cloudy something at the bottom. He watches her d for a moment. We can see how much he likes her. Seeing hi Maggie stops dancing, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Wow. Swift. She tries to take the jar, but Guy swoops it away from he and washes it off in the kitchen sink, then swaddles it i tea towel like a newborn.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Of course when there’s an actual lady involved, it’s a different story. I made you extra...just in case you spill some. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He hands her the bundle gently, as if it were already a b

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Guy. This is really great.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Super. He just stands there. Now what? He fishes his phone out o his pocket and turns the lens on himself, Maggie, and the container, which he gets her to hold up. Maggie is embarrassed and confused.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Selfie. Click! INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - BATHROOM - NIGHT 25 Insert close up: Maggie, wearing blue surgical gloves, fi a plastic syringe with Guy’s sperm.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - BATHROOM —- LATER 26 Maggie has a thermometer in her mouth, syringe in one han She takes out the thermometer, reads her temperature, the punches the number into her phone. A voice calls out of t phone: “you have a: seventy-one percent chance of being fertile right now”. The phone rings. Maggie puts it on speaker phone. INT. TONY AND FELICIA’S KITCHEN - INTERCUT 27

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Did you do it yet?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: My apps are giving me contradictory information. Maybe I should wait.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I would wait. For like five years.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Let me talk to Felicia. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Felicia takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to him. He’s losing his mind.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (Os) Yeah, he seems a little on edge.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: You think so? He’s driving me crazy with theories of mental illness in Guy Childers’ family.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (in BG, grating parmesan) I met his mother once. She had a face like a hatchet and she never stopped sighing. And she DRANK.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: Tony just loves you too much. He wants to keep you for himself.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You know that’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: He doesn’t want you to move on to the next step in your life because then he, too, might actually have to grow up.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (from back of the kitchen) Will you shut the fuck up? Felicia smiles, giving Tony a semi-jovial middle finger.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (thermometer in her mouth) How high does your temperature have to be?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think just slightly elevated.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you talking about the temperature? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (yelling) A hundred and one! It has to be a hundred and one degrees!

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: (to Tony) When was the last time you ovulated?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I read about it. Back at Maggie’s apartment, the camera leaves Maggie, beg to move through Maggie’s living room, toward the buzzer, a curious animal with a will of its own.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: (OS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it doesn’t usually work the first time anyway... My girl friend, Odette...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (OS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odette? That woman is nuts!

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: (OS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just hate her cause she’s a performance artist. Close on the buzzer, which buzzes, LOUD.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (OS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Hold on. Wait! The doorbell goes off again, for a really long time. Some wants in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Felicia, OS) Bye! INT. TONY AND FELICIA’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. Tony is still grating parmesan. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You had her speak at Max’s class, and she said the words “MY VAGINA” three times. INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - NIGHT Maggie is wiggling along the floor on her back, pelvis 35. 28 up wearing surgical gloves and her night gown. The buzzer ri again.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m coming!

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: (OS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie have you done it yet?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (OS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you done it? Finally Maggie reaches the door, reaches up with one leg, answers the buzzer with her toe.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (yelling) Hello!?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (os) It’s John. Reflexively, she jumps to her feet, looks down.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, shoot!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! I just need a minute! Maggie runs into the bathroom. INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - BATHROOM - NIGHT 29 Jump Cut: Maggie takes a quick shower -- see her from out the shower reaching for the soap with a surgical-gloved h  30 31 32 33 36. EXT. MAGGIE’S BUILDING - NIGHT 30 John waiting. He looks like a man about to go into the ri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie pulls on another nearly identical night gown, but one has sleeves. INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - NIGHT 31 Maggie streaks into the kitchen holding the jar with the remains of the sperm in it, sticks it in the freezer. Bac the buzzer with paper towels and sterilizing spray, she m up the mess. At last, having tidied up all evidence, she presses the buzzer.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: John? Are you still there?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah? Maggie buzzes him in. INT./EXT. MAGGIE’S BUILDING - VESTIBULE - NIGHT 32 John comes through the metal gate and approaches the fron door. INT. MAGGIE’S SUBLET - NIGHT 33 He comes in. He’s very tense, seems upset. They talk in t doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I got locked out. Georgette is in Pennsylvania with the kids...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh! Do you want to stay on the couch? John looks at the couch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Not really. He walks in. Sits on the couch. Maggie, thrown by his presence, starts making conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: So I’m on chapter five. Now I think Mrs. Jeffries is my favorite character. She’s so pallid and reliable but he finds her so attractive, in spite of her moustache. I just wonder...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: If maybe the wife’s behavior is getting a little... large?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You should come over to my house. That book is like a documentary. No, I’m sure you’re right. I’m sure I’m exaggerating her behavior. His face is filled with distress. He gets up and paces.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No it’s really funny! I don’t want you to change it. Maybe it’s more about, like how much of it you do.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ah, fuck it! He suddenly falls to his knees at Maggie’s feet and cling the hem of her long night gown. Maggie is astonished. Joh looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m genuinely locked out of my apartment. But I’m also in love with you. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I don’t want to be married to Georgette anymore. And please could I stay in your bed? She doesn’t say anything, doesn’t move. It is only now re hitting her how she feels about this man. She is finally admitting it to herself. He unbuttons the lowest button o her long night gown. She looks down at him, desire bloomi Another button. Another. All the way up, until we glimpse naked breasts between the crack in the cloth. They are fa to face. He whispers.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to have a baby with the pickle man.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I want you to have a baby with me... She wants him terribly but she just has to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I need to tell you something. I...tried already.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Recently...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It didn’t work! It didn’t work. I just had to tell you because...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Because why?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Because I love you. I’m in love with you. They look at one another, and they kiss. They move onto t bed. Maggie looks up at John with open, frank sexuality. has never felt this way before. He leans down to kiss her (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There is a flare of light from the bedside lamp which obscures the image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buttery sunlight flares in the lens. Gradually through th flare we see Maggie from behind carrying her 2 1/2 year o daughter, Lily, on her hip. A long dolly shot: She walks the mailbox at the end of the street and lets Lily mail a bill. Then they walk back and we see them from the front. Bliss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie carries Lily to their storefront loft, opens the b metal door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John types in his glassed-in office. “Dancing in the Dark Bruce Springsteen is blasting. Maggie walks in with Lily her hip and turns down the music after a panicked moment looking for the ipad. Lily stomps in and jumps up and dow

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Daddy! Lily goes off to play. John comes out of his office.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You turned down my song.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It was very loud.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That’s the point.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, shall I turn it up again?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You really are from Wisconsin, arent’t you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes I am. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them are eating soup. Happy.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Can you watch her for an hour, I have a conference call.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ah-- I was going to keep writing, but sure. Maggie stands and hands Lily over to John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, girl, let’s make a big mess.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Can I bring Froggy?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sure. Bring Froggy. 40. 35 36 Lily clutches a little plastic green frog as John carries into the kitchen. They begin to play. INT. QUEENS LOFT - MAGGIE’S WORK SPACE - DAY Maggie is on her call.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. The last time we spoke you wanted to do something with skateboarding and architecture. Is that still what you’re thinking?

dialogues.speaker: HIGGS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Absolutely. I want to be a fragile little human, scaling some big architectural monolith -- asserting my value even as I glide along the surface of some priceless building... 37 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (dreamy, searching) Right. Like... skateboarding down the ramp of the Guggenheim... A phone rings OS.

dialogues.speaker: HIGGS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah! Exactly! That’s perfect.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean the actual Guggenheim.

dialogues.speaker: HIGGS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why not? From across the loft Maggie hears:

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mommy!!! Mommy!!!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me a minute. (hitting ‘mute’ ) John?! No answer. Maggie gets up and walks toward the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Froggy is drowning!

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Froggy is drowning, Mommeeee!!!! John is on the phone. He looks toward the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to Lily) Hold on a second...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Sorry about this but I have another urgent call. I’1l be right back on. Maggie rushes to the bathroom.  38 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily is screaming, looking into the toilet. Maggie walks

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Froggy fell in, and then he was hungry. Maggie looks into the toilet. There is a box of Koala Cri in the toilet, along with half the box of cereal.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Wow, Lily. This is a big mess.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (OS talking into the phone) I could send you the next couple chapters...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Where is Froggy?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Under there.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. We're gonna save him! She retrieves the frog from the toilet and puts him in th sink.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Can I wash him, Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, let’s wash him. Don’t touch him yet...

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I wanna wash him...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: See, we saved him! Lily peers over the side of the sink as Maggie washes the frog in hot water. Her little cheeks are tear stained.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Sorry Froggy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Remembering her call, Maggie un-mutes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hello? No one there. Great. John ends his call. He looks happy. meet outside the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Did you take care of Froggy?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (keeping up her good humor) Yeah, but why didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That guy from Parallel Press called.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh great, what did he say?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He wants to meet me at four.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: But you were taking Lily this afternoon because I have a meeting with a student?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Maybe I can push it. John is hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But who is going to pick up Paul and Justine?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck. All right. He starts for the phone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No--It’s okay -- I’1ll reschedule my meeting.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You don’t mind?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Thanks. She goes back into the bathroom. John makes for his study The phone rings again. John turns and answers.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello...he what??... All right, hang on. John turns to Maggie, who is still in her rubber gloves.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paul twisted his ankle in eurythmics. You’re gonna have to leave now. Close on Maggie as she digests this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a nice private school for Danes, nestled in a townhouse. Maggie, Lily on her hip, emerges from the scho opening the heavy door for Paul, who is now nine. He is o crutches and looks very sorry for himself.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where’s Dad?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He’s in a meeting sweetie, but crutches! Wow. Does it hurt a lot? Paul is upset. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l 42 45. CONTINUED: 4l

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have a while before Justine gets out. Maggie helps the kids into the car, walks to the driver’s side and loads in the crutches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Lily are laughing hysterically in the back seat. They are making a great deal of noise. Maggie has her eye shut. The phone rings. Maggie has to answer this one.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hello? Oh thank you so much for calling me back. Excuse me-- Maggie puts her hand over the phone and talks to Paul in back seat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paul can you check what’s taking Justine so long? Paul hurries out of the car. As he enters the school, Mag notices that he has forgotten his crutches and is running his hurt foot.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for holding. I was hoping to schedule a meeting, we have a grad student -- A student at the New School, Komiko Krauss, just patented a toy we’d love to have a chance to present --Yes. The doll. Yes. Oh great. Ten on Wednesday is fine. Thank you. Bye! As Maggie talks we see Justine helping Paul walk out of t school. He has remembered his injury and is hopping on on leg. Justine Gets in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: Hi. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Got caught up in the locker room?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: (quiet) I couldn't find my shoes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, we’re all here now!

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: What’s for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Good question. I’1l pick something up. Daddy’s at a meeting.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: When’s Mom coming home?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. But I bet there’s a plan! The van drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is on the corded phone with Georgette.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Georgette. The advance is only five thousand more, so why would you not go to the house with the better editor? You keep talking in circles. Munroe is the better editor for this book... For all the reasons we've been talking about! Maggie raps on the glass of his office and cheerfully hol up a bag of Take-Out. He waves at her, still immersed in conversation.  45 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chinese food cartons going in the garbage. Maggie is clea up the remains of take-out as John flops onto the couch, seemingly exhausted. Maggie sits down at the end of the couch.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: So how was the meeting at Parallel Press?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I had to push it to Thursday. Georgette was having one of her crises. I couldn’t get her off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She got offers from two different UK publishers for her new book and she couldn't decide.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Wow. She doesn’t have anyone else to talk to about something like this except her ex-husband? Especially since her new book is all about our affair and how it ruined her life?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I messed up your day.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Not just my day. Komiko -- my student. She’s a fragile person... and I had a meeting set up to discuss her meeting with the toy company. But I had to cancel that meeting because you had a meeting. And then you don’t even go to the meeting with the publisher because you were talking Georgette out of her tree! Why does nobody ever talk me out of my tree?!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (with affection) Because you’re never up a tree. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And if you were, you would find your way back down all by yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Am I so, so capable that I don’t deserve any attention, is that it? Like, the squeaky wheel gets the grease, and the cactus never gets watered? Attempting to defuse her, John takes off one of Maggie’s socks and A beat. starts giving her a foot rub.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to start thinking of yourself as indispensable, John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (removing the other long knee sock) But I’m not. I’m totally dispensable. On a practical level, you'd be fine without me.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you realize that Paul faked the ankle thing today just so you would pick him up from school, and then you didn’t even show.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He ran on it when I asked him to go check on Justine. He forgot.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That’s weird.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No. It’s not weird. You want to know why? Because his mother is in Reykjavik right now, studying the maternal techniques of the Icelandic. He needs his father’s attention. So do I. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Let’s go away for a couple days when Georgette gets back. Just the two of us. Maggie sighs, looks at him. She doesn’t really want to go away just the two of them at this moment.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to start pouting more.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (relieved at this levity) Georgette’1l give you a tutorial. She’s good at that. Close on Maggie. She smiles a sad, tired, alienated smile

dialogues.speaker: EXT-
dialogues.text: Maggie walking beside Lily, who is pushing the stroller.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Who did you sit with at snack?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Alison.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (OS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie? Maggie turns as the camera pans to see Guy, the pickle entrepreneur, near-father of her child, king of his booth

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh hi! Hi, Guy! I haven’t seen you for so long...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Lily) This is my friend Guy. Guy comes out of his booth and kneels before Lily, gazing the little girl with something like reverence.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Is that... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (blank at first, then copping on to his assumption) ?... Oh, no -- this is Lily. I got married. I should have told you. I met my husband around the same time you gave me the...sample. An awkward moment.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Intense. I just found out Whole Foods is going to be carrying my pickles nationally. We have to expand production, post-haste!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's amazing.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I’m manning the stall to get away from the chaos at the factory.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (a sudden impulse) Oh! Do you still have those Bavarian pickles?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Sure do. Our most popular pickle.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Can I buy a large jar please?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: When are we gonna eat the pickles?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Lily) Let’s go get some pickles.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: One large Bavarian. He goes back to the booth and hands Maggie a huge jar of pickles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's the biggest jar of pickles I’ve ever seen. How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (glum) Wedding present.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Bye! Maggie picks up Lily and puts the jar of pickles in the stroller. Guy watches them go. He and Lily wave to one another. As Maggie and Lily walk off:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, wiglet. I’m so glad you're you! 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear John’s dot matrix printer OS. Maggie is at the kitch table, the huge jar of Guy’s pickles before her. She reac in and takes out a pickle, chomps down. Yum. John walks i and hands her the latest pages from his manuscript. She t them with an air of resignation.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (touching the paper) Wow. Still warm. Maggie starts reading as John goes into the bedroom. He speaks through the open hatch.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Georgette cancelled her trip. Maggie nods, reading.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So she’s gonna want the kids next week after all. Maggie is still reading. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m Mrs. Jeffries, aren’t I?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm the colorless, efficient postal worker that you fell in love with because she makes your life so much easier.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (put out) I came up with Mrs. Jeffries before we even met.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you turned me into her then. He makes a helpless, fed up gesture.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At least I don’t have a moustache -- yet. INT. QUEENS LOFT BEDROOM —- MORNING Maggie and John read in bed. Maggie reads a newspaper; Jo reads the Paris Review. Maggie smiles at something in the paper.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you want to hear your horoscope?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (immersed) No. Close on Maggie as she looks at him, a terrible thought g through her head.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm terrified that I’m falling out of love with him. Really out of love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide shot: Maggie is walking Lily in the stroller. Beside walks Tony, who pushes Max, now six. Max is reading a thi book by the light of a tiny clamp light. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Felicia and I fall in and out of love pretty much every week. You can’t be so idealistic.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I wanted to help him become a fiction writer... and now all he does is write. The novel is like five hundred pages long and I don’t even think it’s half done.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Have you read it all?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Most of it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Still like it?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s getting more and more... complicated. Is it possible to be too smart to be a novelist?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I haven't heard of that.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you think I have something wrong with me?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, like I have a condition. Where I always fall out of love.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maggie stops, and whacks Tony in the arm.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Shut up! Really?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes! No! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You seriously think I have a condition?!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No! I don’t know. Maybe. No. No, you don’t. Maybe you haven’t met the right guy yet. Ask Felicia. Don’t ask me. I’m not the right guy. They keep walking. Maggie looks down at Max reading in hi stroller.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Does he ever walk?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (as if this explains it) He’s gotta finish that book by Friday. ‘Does he ever walk’. He’s captain of the soccer team.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What is it, stroller soccer?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You're hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the arch of Washington Square Park, pedestrians passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgette

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (OS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be honest with you.

dialogues.speaker: STORE
dialogues.text: is reading from her book to a healthy crowd.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: This book was born from pain. My husband, whom I am not ashamed to say I loved with all my heart, though we had a difficult relationship, had an affair with a younger woman, left me, and started a new family. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Georgette is baring her soul, Maggie and Felicia walk at the back of the room. Hearing the text, Maggie immedia hides behind a book case and they both grab glasses of wi peeking out to watch. Georgette has not noticed them. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) And what I gleaned from this exquisite torture are the thoughts which this act of betrayal to me as a woman provoked in me as an anthropologist. I must ask myself: is the contemporary obsession with exclusive possession ruining our chances of marital happiness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reading is over. People mill about, talking. Georgett at the bar getting a glass of champagne when she spots Maggie, who is talking to Felicia.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Maggie?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes! Felicia sidles off to the other side of the room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I recognized you from a picture on Justine’s phone.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah, I -- I wanted to hear your reading, it was really... Maggie can’t find a word to describe it. Georgette looks her intently.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I want to thank you. For taking such good care of the children, while I have been gone. I know it’s been a burden. I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You’re -- you’re welcome. They’re wonderful kids. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: We should get together some time. I feel I have been rather childish about this. I have to face the fact that we are raising them together... the three of us. Georgette has an imperious seductiveness which is impossi to resist.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Yes. I would love to.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Call me some time. It’s easy to get my number! Maggie is left standing there, besotted and shocked. She moves to the end of the signing line, beside Felicia, who bought a copy of “Bring Back the Geisha”.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You bought a book?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: I couldn’t resist.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do we need to get it signed?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: I think we do.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Georgette is fascinating. She's vulnerable, and powerful, and warm, and charming all at once... Now I get why he was so obsessed with her.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: I don’t think ‘easy to live with’ is on that list, though.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I like her. I actually like her! I’m such a blockhead. I always thought I was rescuing John from this monstrous egomaniac so he could finally write his book, and that I knew better how to run his life -- I was going to fix everything. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he’s totally self-absorbed while I do every single practical thing and make the money. And on top of that, I... if it weren’t for Lily I'd say I’d made a terrible mistake.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: (joking--with a glance at Georgette, signing books) Too bad you can’t just give him back to his ex-wife. Maggie looks over at Georgette with a laugh. But we move closer and closer on her face until... she’s not smiling anymore. She’s thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is sucking the grease off his fingers. Maggie stares him, no longer charmed by his barbarous eating habits. Th kids are speaking Danish.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: (in Danish) I hate brussels sprouts.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (in Danish) They're a little hard. Maggie looks over at the kids, totally alienated from her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie walks along a Korea Town street, and into the gate the 17th century Quaker meeting house. A battered sign re “Quaker Meeting. All Welcome.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High wide shot: the meeting house is empty, but for Maggi who sits on a wooden bench. We move in closer as she wait for inspiration, some clue as to what to do about her existence. At the end of the push in, she looks up: she’s it.  51 58. EXT. GEORGETTE’S BUILDING - DAY 51 Maggie parks outside Georgette’s elegant Harlem brownston Justine and Paul get out of the van, Justine lugging a stuffed duffel bag.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: So now it suits the captors for the little prisoners to be moved.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aren’t you excited to see Mama?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: Of course I’m excited to see Mama. I’m just sick of never knowing which house any of my stuff is in. I can’t wait to be a grown up, so I can have kids and push them around. Maggie, not hearing this, stands on the street scrutinizi the parking sign. Paul and Justine watch her, speaking Danish, their secret language.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Danish w subtitles) Sometimes I wonder if she is a little dim-witted. What is she doing?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (in Danish) She’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: (in Danish) You're like a dog. You love whoever feeds you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (in Danish) No I don’t!

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: (in English, to Maggie) Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I just can’t believe I actually found a legal parking space right outside your mom’s building. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: You're coming inside?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Just to say hi.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 52
dialogues.text: INT. GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT - KITCHEN - DAY 53 Georgette opens her door.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Hi! Hi--oh, hello, Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: John had a meeting so he asked me to--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Come in. The kids remove their shoes and greet their mother with g affection. Maggie watches this as she removes her penny loafers. Justine is very tender with her mother. Another person. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) (to the kids) I made you a nice snack and you are allowed to watch one single episode of something ghastly while eating it. But no fighting about what it is, Paul. Justine gets to choose. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) The snacks are already in the den. They run up the stairs. Georgette turns to Maggie, who is standing in her socks. Her demeanor is chillier than it w at the book store. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) I was about to make some coffee? Or tea?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Coffee would be great. Thank you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maggie follows Georgette toward the kitchen. The living r is a symphony in taupe. Large photographs of Geishas from 1920’s now dominate the walls.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your place is really nice.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Columbia housing! INT. GEORGETTE’S KITCHEN - DAY Georgette puts brewed coffee in a blender and holds a sti of butter.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I put butter in mine. It nullifies afternoon sugar cravings.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Great. Plop goes the butter. Georgette throws the blender into h gear as Maggie backs out. INT. GEORGETTE’S LIVINGROOM - DAY While Georgette blends the butter next door, Maggie walks through the room, drawn to a beautiful black and white im of a younger John holding Justine. Maggie doesn’t notice Georgette coming up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: That’s a lovely photo, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (startled by her) Yes. Thanks. She sips the buttered coffee --ack! Georgette sips hers w maintaining eye contact with Maggie. A sort of “O.K. Corr moment. MAGGIE (CONT’D) It’s good to finally meet you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I won’t pretend it doesn’t cost me something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I’m not into fakery.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I detest the role of the spurned wife, I won’t play it--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're not.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Am I not?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You still -- have such a deep connection to John. Georgette invites Maggie to sit down.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: We have managed to remain friends, it’s true... Georgette is looking at Maggie with surprise and a little suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I mean, your phone calls...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Do you disapprove of them?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: The marriage has dissolved, but we are still parenting together.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, I mean, it’s more than just parenting, you guys are on the phone several times a day. Don’t get me wrong, I think it’s great. So...I... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Georgette is looking at her carefully. Maggie’s cheeks ar going hot, her heart is speeding up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s obvious you’re still in love with him. A moment of silence, of disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you playing at? Maggie decides to jump off the cliff.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: John and I are in trouble. And I don’t think he realizes how badly in trouble we are. Or he doesn’t want to know. And then, when I saw you at the reading...I realized-- that there might be an opportunity, an opening... somehow...to get the two of you... back together.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I see. I see... Maggie nods hopefully. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) So you're tired of your little affair. You are all done with it. And now you want to make sure you don't feel guilty, so you’re going to manipulate us all into some absurd happy ending! Georgette stands, looking down at Maggie, who is shrinkin the second. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) I have met a lot of control freaks in my life, in fact I even thought I was one -- but you make me look like an amateur.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to insult you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Have the decency to leave him and face the fact that you poisoned my life, and my children’s lives, and probably John’s life with your own selfishness. That’s your burden. You earned it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Wait a minute. If you had such a perfect marriage why was John miserable? You neglected him. You used him. You didn’t respect his talent!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: If I am so awful, what the hell are you doing here trying to get him back together with me?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
