dialogues.text: I just think that actually, even though I do think you were pretty self-absorbed and extremely needy, he needs it -- it actually kept John in balance. Taking care of you made him think about someone other than himself.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Leave. Leave. Leave.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Leave my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh! You want me to leave. Okay. I’m leaving. Maggie gets out as fast as she possibly can. EXT. GEORGETTE’S BROWNSTONE- DAY 54 The door shuts behind Maggie. She’s shaken, her shoes in hand. Looks over at her van. There’s a parking ticket wed under the wiper.  64. 57 INT. TONY & FELICIA’S APARTMENT —- LATE AFTERNOON 57 It’s already dark out. Maggie is lying on the couch as To shuttles in and out of the room cleaning up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I have never been so humiliated in my life. I’m in such deep oatmeal. What was I thinking?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Maybe you had a psychotic episode.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: But it’s a really good idea! Tony emerges from the hallway looking rumpled and disgruntled.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Life doesn’t work that way, you dufus. You can’t stuff what’s already happened back in the box. God I really think you need help.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Why are you being so hostile?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Because this pisses me off! The whole thing pisses me off.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Why can’t you just leave your husband, like any normal human being?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Because it would be such a waste.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: A waste! You’re such a hall monitor. It’s not a waste. He’s not a paper product. Love is messy, okay? It’s illogical and wasteful and it’s messy. And it leaves these loose threads sticking out all over the place. But you! You like things neat and tidy and ethical. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you messed that up the minute you got with a married man.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're not being my friend right now.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh yes I am. I am being your friend. This is being your friend. I’m being honest with you. Good intentions. You're all about good intentions. Little Miss Quaker Two Shoes is gonna do the right thing. But you always somehow screw it up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (actually wounded now) Screw you.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah, screw me. Fine. She stands up and starts putting on her coat as Tony tidi up the living room, muttering to himself. She is on her w to the door when she stops, filled up with emotion. She cries, suddenly, hard, and sits down helplessly. Tony not and kneels beside her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Maggie. Hey. I’m sorry. Maggie sits, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (gently) What about Lily, huh? Fathers are a good thing too. He wipes away a tear from her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (through her tears) I know that, I know that. But... I’m just as afraid of her growing up inside a dead marriage as growing up without her dad in the same house. Kids can tell when people are pretending.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Maggie. It’s a tough one. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She sits still for a long moment. That earnest little fac Trying to figure out the right thing to do again. Click. She's decided. She wipes her tears.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay, okay, okay, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is sitting in John’s Central American hammock as h writes furiously. She looks at peace.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes please.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yes please what.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes please let’s do something, just us. If the offer’s still good. He looks up at her, uncertain, but game.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe a local adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic and lights strung up. A busy Chinatown street.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 60
dialogues.text: INT. CHINESE RESTAURANT/HOTEL- DAY Aé1 John walks in with Maggie. The restaurant is empty but fo two waiters setting up tables. A young Chinese Woman look them quizzically from behind a high desk with a large CAS ONLY sign displayed. He approaches the woman behind the counter. Maggie hangs back. He’s speaking very low. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hi. My name is Johnny Harding. I was hoping to speak to Wang. Is he downstairs? The young woman looks doubtful, but eventually she walks to one of the waiters and whispers in his ear. Maggie mak move to join John but John tells her to stay where she is The waiter walks up to John with an impassive expression. John puts his hand on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Johnny Harding. The waiter nods. John gestures to Maggie to follow. They follow the man down a set of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and John follow the waiter through the kitchen. A is making dumplings with lightning speed. Maggie looks at him, totally confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and John emerge in a room furnished only with gamb tables and a TV on the wall playing a Chinese soap opera. Chinese men and a few women are playing Mahjong, poker, a blackjack. Everyone seems to be smoking. There are only a handful of non-Chinese players. The gamblers look up at t two new outsiders as they walk by.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to Maggie) My dad used to take me to the owner’s old place. The waiter leads them to a black jack table where he conf briefly with an older man, and then turns. John hands the waiter a role of bills, enough to be in the game. John an Maggie sit down. A hostess places two tea cups full of clear liquid on the blackjack table and the older man starts dealing. Maggie takes a sip of the liquid in the teacup and does a double take.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What’s in this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Just drink it, ok? The dealer deals out the cards. John plays a hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is for all the marbles. Maggie, who doesn’t know how to play, is watching the act rapt. John wins. It takes her a second to realize it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We won! We won! She kisses his cheek. She’s gone through a few cups of th “tea” the hostess keeps pouring in everyone’s cup, and sh getting tipsy. She and John are flirting, having fun. The scene becomes a montage of gamblers, cards, music, drinki Maggie taps her card with a little swagger.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that good? Right?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No? Their chips are swept away.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughing) No! Please no. Where did they go? They are having fun. She is served a beer, takes a slug.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drown my sorrows.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Slow down on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and John eat. John is telling a story. Maggie is having a great time. She pulls a swig of beer from the bottle.  63 64 65 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Maggie stagger up to the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We'd like a room for the night.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: This is a hotel?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It is a hotel if you know it’s a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh-ho!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Thank you. What do I owe you? A hundred fifty dollars? I got a hundred fifty dollars. Maggie is behind John. She shoves her hands in John’s poc and fishes out some bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall into the room, laughing on the floor. John drag off Maggie's dress before he’s even closed the door. She bounds onto the bed in her slip.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Take off your clothes! She miaows like a cat, hisses, paws up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Five! Four! Three! Two! One! He leaps on her and drags off her tights as she screams w laughter.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take off your fucking tights! Close on her feet as she gives way to pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. John is eating breakfast; Maggie is sit in a pool of light on the bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (exploring-- not imploring) Would you ever want another baby?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (tossing it off) I’ll never finish the book if I don’t knuckle down and concentrate. Four kids is a lot. His reaction feels like a slap in the face.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You wouldn't notice. It’s just one more kid for you to ignore. John stops. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What kind of thing is that to say?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s a true thing, John. You -- I -- I’m supporting you so you can write and that’s the deal and I accept it but -- I feel like I’m your intern. Or your nanny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: For Christ’s sake. You set all this up! You took over, gave everybody a job. My job is to write my novel so that’s what I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I know that’s what you’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You can’t get mad when we all play our parts to perfection. This stings her.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you even like me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What are you trying to get me to tell you? Huh? Maybe I should be asking you that question. He walks out and leaves her there.  66 67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Maggie walk beside each other in total alienatio

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WASHINGTON SQUARE- DAY
dialogues.text: The arch reminds us of happier times between John and Mag

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEW SCHOOL COURTYARD- DAY
dialogues.text: The phallic bench reminds us of happier times between Joh and Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students and teachers flow in and out of the glass doors, creating liquid reflections on the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is working on her computer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: May I sit down? Maggie jumps.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sure. Georgette looks around, as if for people she knows, then sits. A moment of silence. Maggie waits for the blow.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: In December, I am attending a conference in Canada on Fictocritical Anthropology.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Fictocritical Anthropology is John’s field. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I know, but -- You mean...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (cold) I’m in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: ...Really?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I have no reason to trust you. On the other hand, I have absolutely nothing to lose. I could easily arrange to have John invited to give a paper at the conference.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you think he would accept?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Zizek is speaking. He loves Zizek. Maggie takes this in. She can’t quite believe it’s happen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is putting away dishes; John is fixing a lamp. He waits for a while to speak.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I got invited to give a paper ata conference.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Really? That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah--except it’s all the way up in Quebec. So I can’t go.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No-- You have to go.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Because you... you would probably like a break. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but Georgette’s out of town that week, too. I can’t leave you alone with all the kids.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Of course you can! I’1l be fine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Zizek is speaking...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh you love Zizek!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (baffled) How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I--I think I heard you mention him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Canadian Airlines plane flies through a sunny sky. EXT. Quebec HOTEL - DAY 74 A stone building, rustic in aspect. A large sign reads:

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOLOGISTS
dialogues.text: John walks into the building. Snow has begun to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John walks into the dining area. A sprinkling of academic young man in a baggy sweater comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: AL BENTWAITHE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. John Harding?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ~” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AL BENTWAITHE
dialogues.text: I--I’m reading “Rituals of Commodity Fetishism at the Tail End of the Empire”.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How are you making out?

dialogues.speaker: AL BANTWAITHE
dialogues.text: It’s tremendous. We all came up here just to hear you speak. And Zizek, obviously.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: AL BENTWAITHE
dialogues.text: This is a little fetish-y but-- Could you sign my book?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sure. What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: AL BENTWAITHE
dialogues.text: Al. As John signs the book, he spies Georgette from behind. AL BENTWAITHE (CONT’D) Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Take care John makes his way across the room, toward Georgette.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fancy meeting you here.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'm giving a paper.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you write me you were coming here? I mean, I knew you’d be away... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t know... I must have mentioned it. Are you sorry you came?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Not at all. It’s big enough for the both of us. Isn’t it? You look really well.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I feel well. Beautiful here, ya?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yes. Great air... so far. John looks at the empty seat beside her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you mind? Or should we try not to co-mingle?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: It’s fine, why not? We are friends. (introducing the woman next to her) This is Debbie Wasserman. From Yale.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE WASSERMAN
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. After a brief, awkward smile that says she knows a lot ab John and Georgette’s divorce, Debbie turns to the dining partner on her left.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (to John) Did Maggie tell you we met?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yes. She enjoyed meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: She's an interesting person.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, very surprising. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How did you have time to be surprised?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You know how it is, we all concoct ideas of what our rival will be like. But she’s not my rival anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Paul told me Maggie taught him to do a figure eight when she took him ice skating the other day. He was very proud.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She's great with him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: She seems like a very capable person.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She’s a natural mother. Georgette looks like she’s been sucker-punched. Georgette after her,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: She sounds like a wonderful partner for you. I -- I need to make a phone call. I promised...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Aren’t you going to eat?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I’m not really hungry. Oh and -- maybe you’re right, it’ll be a mistake if we co-mingle too much. We'll only end up getting on each other’s nerves. leaves, angry -- at herself, mostly. John looks confused. The sound of the wind picks up.  76 77 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning, Maggie is having a meeting with Komiko, Japanese design graduate student, and some poker-faced to executives. Komiko demonstrates her patented doll, unzipp it to reveal a string of cloth intestines.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Komiko has designed the first patented doll with removable internal organs.

dialogues.speaker: KOMIKO
dialogues.text: (whispery) Sixty percent of children have fears about death.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Komiko’s idea is, to relieve children’s fears about the body by helping them see what’s inside.

dialogues.speaker: KOMIKO
dialogues.text: (removing the intestine) They can draw on the organs.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: But all the elements are completely washable. So...We think this would appeal to parents interested in marriage-based toys. I mean, knowledge. Knowledge-based toys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow is falling on the landscape. Whirling. The wind is ferocious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In New York, it’s two hours later. Maggie is folding laun with Justine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (os) There’s no heat. The fucking internet doesn’t work.  78 79 78.

dialogues.speaker: QUEENS LOFT
dialogues.text: John, depressed, is on his phone in a corner of the bar a the end of the dining room. There is a kerosene lamp besi him. It’s still snowing. Outside, all is white. Intercut Maggie in the loft.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: The generator blew up. My batteries are about to die. And get this. Guess who’s here. Georgette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is painting Justine’s fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Really? Wow. How is that?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Her mood matches the weather.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How are you guys doing?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Everyone's fine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can’t get any information about when the airport is opening up. So it looks like I’m stuck here! They're breaking out the snowshoes, which, to me, is ominous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is having a bubble bath with Lily. They are having fun, blowing bubbles through a little plastic ring. Lily the ring into the bottle of bubble stuff, blows a big one watches it float through the air.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh that’s a good one... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: How much? Wait, I know, twenty-five three hundred and sixty two!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's exactly right! They continue to blow bubbles.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to live inside a bubble.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (watching the bubble float) Me too.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But I want my own bubble.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay. We can each have a bubble.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: And Daddy gets his own bubble too. Maggie blows a huge bubble and looks inside it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I can see Daddy in his bubble. Maggie looks inside the bubble. Slow dissolve into: A sno landscape/ John and Georgette and a few others are on snowshoes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low wide shot: John and Georgette walk in a line of acade on snowshoes. Georgette falls over, letting out a cry. Jo turns but she waves him off and continues. Closer frontal shot: Georgette falls again. John can’t he stopping to help her up. She dusts herself off grumpily. both look up the mountain to see the rest of the academic have trudged off without them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Typical.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We can just follow their tracks back. They snowshoe together in silence. Time passes. 80. 80

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nothing really looks familiar. Does it? CLOSE UP OF THEIR SNOWSHOES CUTTING INTO A VIRGIN DRIFT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are trudging along, deep in conversation, We see them through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You know that talk you gave yesterday was just great. I didn’t even know you were working in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I guess you haven’t seen anything I’ve written for a while.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, I miss that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I used to like that. You know, I miss that, showing each other stuff. totally lost. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (encouraged, plunging in) Forget me -- that talk you gave yesterday was the hit of the conference.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It was just all the old ideas.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You altered that passage on de Tocqueville.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nothing gets by you!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Your work feels so fresh... No one unpacks commodity fetishism like you do.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Aw, shucks. A few exhausting steps through the snow, walking toward c up. Then:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Are you still working on that novel?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: How's it coming?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (brusque) Fine. He moves a little ahead. Doesn’t want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ~” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t mean to be insulting about your fiction. It’s just that I am so proud of the academic work you've done. You see, here, how much people love it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m not abandoning anything. Come on. I don’t want you to get too cold. Something about that little protective statement makes Georgette sad. She loves him so much. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I have something I want to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: For being so self-centered. For not listening to you, to what you needed, for not investing in your work--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, you don’t have to--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I think I was just so, so tied up in succeeding, in making a name for myself, I stopped paying attention to us, to you, to our marriage. And now, I have success, and it’s as if I’ve emerged from a tunnel. I hope... in the future, to be less self-absorbed. If I ever get another chance... at love. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Of course you'll get another chance.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I bet they’re lining up. Georgette’s eyes fill with tears. This whole thing is too much for her. She sinks down into the snow and cries.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Are we going to die here?!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, God. (yelling) HELLO? HELLO?!

dialogues.speaker: HEY, ALL YOU FRENCH CANADIAN
dialogues.text: PEOPLE! WE’RE FREEZING OUT HERE AND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Georgette enter, covered in snow.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (to the waiter who opens the door) We were lost. They follow the waiter who holds a torch, walking toward raucous music. A Québécois acoustic duo, a man and a woma is playing “Dancing in the Dark” by Bruce Springsteen on guitar and Harmonium on a makeshift stage. The male singe has a thick French Canadian accent. Georgette and John pl down on a couch, strip off their huge jackets, and take glasses of cognac offered to them. They sing along to “Dancing in the Dark”, laughing. This is an old favorite theirs, from early times. Debbie Wasserman dances wildly. Bentwaithe joins her. Something is happening between thos two. Then, John can’t help it, he wants to dance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes Georgette’s hand and they dance along with all t other tipsy academics. Georgette is radiant. They seem so happy and free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Georgette are sitting together on the couch by t fire, drinking cognac. They are almost the only ones here There is a striking intimacy between them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’ve written myself so far up my own ass I can’t see my way out. The whole story bores me to death.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: So stop writing it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I feel like if I don’t produce some kind of masterpiece, Maggie will give up on me. That book is a big part of what made her fall for me. But, Georgette. If I have learned one thing in the last three years...it’s that I’m not a novelist!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: If she truly loves you... she’1ll love you whether you are a novelist or a garbage collector. A long pause as he looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You did, didn’t you. You loved me that way. She says nothing. A moment between them. Then, a little O World shrug from Georgette. He looks at her. Falling for The lights come on. They blink in the glare. Al Benthwaite walks in at the far end of the room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AL BENTWAITHE, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: They've opened the airport! We can go home tomorrow! Debbie Wasserman hoots off-screen. John and Georgette sit saddened by the news.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I better go pack... She leaves him to think. INT. QUEBEC HOTEL - GEORGETTE’S ROOM - NIGHT 84 Georgette is packing. The lights are on. There is a knock It’s John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: John looks up at her and it’s clear that he loves her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t want to leave you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (ushering him in) John...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I want you so badly. I can’t think about anything else. It’s like it never ended, like the past three years never happened. Or that I’m hallucinating.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: But they did happen. It all happened.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I know. I know!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: We have to stay real. The snow is melting. She is powerfully drawn to him -- and yet -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GEORGETTE (CONT’D) John.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: There’s something you should know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What is it? Georgette pauses, uncertain if she should break the mood spilling the beans about Maggie’s offer. She sits beside looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes closer and closer... and...they kiss and fall o of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie waits, lying on the bed, wondering if the plan is working... INT. QUEBEC HOTEL - DINING AREA —- MORNING 85 Meanwhile, John is tearing into his eggs while reading a by Mick Taussig called, “What Color is the Sacred?” Georg joins him, looking fragrant in a crisp white shirt.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (to waiter with two pots) Coffee please. The waiter pouring the coffee is the same man that rocked Springsteen last night. John half notices this, then look his ex-wife.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Now what.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You regret it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We belong to each other. That’s it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Actually, for me, this was a one- night stand. They are both so happy. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) But seriously. I’ve changed. I know I can live without you now. I just don’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I would like to read your novel now.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I know you have a copy because I saw you marking one up. John reaches into his backpack and pulls out a manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Be careful what you wish for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is sitting on her bed, waiting. Waiting. She hears John’s keys in the door. Fear in her

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hi. He leans in and kisses her swiftly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s Lily?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Felicia wanted to take her to that dance class. 87. 85 massive 86 belly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did your talk go?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Fine, I think. Well attended. I got a few laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Was it okay with Georgette?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She eventually defrosted.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Good. John can’t bear the pressure of the lie.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I should tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay... 88. 86 She sits waiting, her arms clamped around her legs. He si down on the bed again, crushed by guilt, barely able to g the words out.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You know we were snowed in?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So Georgette and I were thrown together for two whole days. And there was this... atmosphere of -- I don’t know, it was very strange. I found myself... unearthing things... old stuff...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Good stuff or bad stuff?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Emotional. Nostalgic - The same stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The same as what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yes. Fuck. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Georgette and I slept together. A long pause. This victory hurts. John sits, his head drooping. Maggie begins to cry. Even this was her idea, it hurts.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Georgette was right.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We should’ve just been an affair. You were having a rough spot in your marriage and I came along and...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But then we wouldn’t have had Lily.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (genuinely torn) It was real between us... all real. When I met you, I was lost. I was a fucking mess. I was so insecure and you...you saved me. You rescued me. I’m sorry. I don’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No I don’t!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You go back to Georgette. If you love her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You think? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maggie nods. She’s very sad, but she knows this is right. John kisses her, then pulls away. He is, it seems, in lov with two women at this moment.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. I don’t know what to do. They sit together.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 87
dialogues.text: EXT. GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT - LATE AFTERNOON A87 Establishing shot. INT. GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT —- LATE AFTERNOON 88 Georgette, John, Justine, and Paul have dinner. Paul is g on about something that happened at school. Justine is staring at John.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: (not hostile, just curious) What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I accidentally ran into your mom at school cause we each thought it was our day to pick up Paul--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was so funny!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: And then your Mom graciously invited me over to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: You guys should learn to coordinate your schedules.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: There’s no harm in spending time together as a family. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: Except for -- isn’t that the point of a divorce? That you’re not a family anymore? INT. GEORGETTE’S APARTMENT —- BEDROOM - LATE AFTERNOON 89 We hear John saying goodbye to the kids off-screen. Georg enters the bedroom, drawing John in with her. They fall o the bed and start fooling around, impatient as teenagers. knock on the locked door. They freeze.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0S)
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (calling out) What is it Paul darling?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0S)
dialogues.text: I’m hungry.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: But you just ate!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0S)
dialogues.text: What can I have?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You can have a plate of saltines, a cheese stick, and an apple. Georgette starts frantically undoing John’s belt buckle.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0S)
dialogues.text: Can you cut up the apple?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Ask Justine.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0S)
dialogues.text: She’s busy. (pause) Mom? John jumps off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (whispering, cinching his belt) This is ridiculous. I have to go. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Where will you stay?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’1l just call some friends--try to avoid a hotel. We've got to give them time to adjust. They kiss. She slips out the door. John waits till she is gone a while, just stands there stock-still.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (os) All right, Paul, here I come to cut up your apple! EXT. GEORGETTE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 90 John making calls, leaving a few messages with various friends he could stay with for the night. Jump cuts as he leaves messages. Then, finally:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Felicia! Thank God you're home...ah, not so good. INT. TONY AND FELICIA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 91 Felicia and John have been talking for a while. Felicia i knitting.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So she already told you guys? She called you?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: She called me. I don’t know about Tony, he’s been out all day.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’d she say? Is she going to be okay?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: You know Maggie. She’s been taking care of herself all her life. I mean, she’s emotional--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: This whole thing feels so unreal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: I know. I think it’s better to be honest. When you can.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m just so surprised!

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: I know. I mean, I can imagine. A fumbling at the lock. Singing. It’s Tony, in a rumpled suit. Three sheets to the wind.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: John! Aren't you in Canada?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: No. He’s here. Tony looks at Felicia. She glares at him to keep silent.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So you won your case?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: We trounced them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What was it about?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Tainted pudding.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: A lawsuit?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What else? Lawsuits keep my wife in post-modern choreography, and me in self-loathing. A good deal all round.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: If you’re going to be in that kind of mood you should just go to bed. Tony is fumbling around in a kitchen cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m craving one little nip of that vanilla whiskey you so lovingly gave me for Christmas, Fi. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: Looks like you’ve had enough of something. Tony holds up a bottle. Talks to John.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: This stuff is like liquid crack. Have some?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Just a finger. Thanks. Tony sits down and grimaces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Aargh.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I sat on my balls.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: I think you should have your balls hemmed. Like that actor -- what’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: Apparently it’s just a few stitches, and -- boop! A ball lift.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (adjusting his seat) So. John. Any news? John looks at Felicia, wondering how much Tony knows.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You haven't spoken to Maggie?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I've been knee-deep in pudding all day.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: John and Maggie are... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John sits 95.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We...

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: He and Georgette...

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (unthinking, drunk) You mean it worked?!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What worked?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (a desperate attempt to recover) Who said that drinks are like tits - - one is too few, three too many?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What worked? What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (looking sick, pushes his drink away) I’m not really much of a drinker.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: No. You’re not. immobile as the terrible logic accrues in him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So this is what Georgette kept almost telling me. Oh, Jesus. Tony and Felicia go into a frenzy of lame denial.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: She might have been trying to tell you--

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You guys set me up?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevated train snakes across the tracks above the sto front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John walks into the room and turns on the light, starts taking his clothes out of the drawers. Maggie wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: John?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Was it a test?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: To see if I really was in love with Georgette, as you apparently suspected? A pause. Maggie feels a little frightened.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You happy now?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Happy isn’t the right word.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t even know what to say. I’m speechless.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We were going to break up. I hada feeling you were still in love with Georgette. And you were, as it turns out.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What about Lily? My daughter. Where does she fit into this plan of yours?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: If we’re going to break up it’s -- better to do it soon, for her sake. So that’s all she remembers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John flips.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But I didn’t want to break up! Because, among other things, I was committed to you and we had a child together.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Not because you wanted to be with me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (on a wave of his own thoughts--packing all the while) So this is the fate you’ve picked out for me -- to just ricochet around the tri-state area, ruining one family after another? I don’t accept that. I didn’t choose this. I can’t believe I let you make me feel so -- so guilty about betraying you and wrecking our marriage, when you masterminded this whole thing, manipulated me into falling for my ex-wife, colluded with her to get me invited to that conference, to make me into some absurd patsy, a pawn in your revolting little narrative. Well guess what? Your puppet is cutting his strings. You can both fuck yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You and Georgette never really stopped being together the whole time we were married.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I mean, you thought it was over, but it never really was. This is the proof, isn’t it. It’s what you wanted. Be honest.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I think the question really is what do you want? What do you want, Maggie Hardin? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I want to live honestly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well you’re not off to a very good start.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want a marriage that’s a lie. I don’t want to tiptoe around our disconnection anymore. You deserve to be with someone who really -- gives herself over to you. I did what I thought was right.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You're very ethical.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You’re the one who slept with someone else.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (laughing in spite of himself) Are you fucking kidding me? John zips up his bag.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the way, just out of curiosity -- did you ever love me?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Of course I did.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What about the kids?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You and Georgette seem to be such good teammates, strategize with her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leaves. Maggie stares at the door he’s walked out of. 94 INT. LILY’S ROOM - DAY 94 Maggie walks Lily’s room and lies on the bed. Lily stirs looks over the railing of her bed.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What Mama?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh wiglet. I did something really stupid. To fix something else I did that turned out wrong. And I thought it was going to end up wonderful. But I made a big mess.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (finally, something she can relate to) You made a mess? Maggie recovers somewhat. Laughs through her tears.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. But I don’t know how to clean it up.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (lying down again) Use a sponge. Just forget about it. Maggie can’t help smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is driving with Lily in the back. 96 INT. GEORGETTE’S KITCHEN - DAY 96 Maggie walks in. Georgette is at the table.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He found out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: How? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Tony. My best friend. He was drunk. It slipped out. Georgette sits down and takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: It was inevitable. I almost told him myself several times.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The tragic flaw in my plan.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think he’s just really sick of both of us. Mostly me. A moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Georgette. I don’t know what to say. Georgette looks at her, deeply.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You're a funny person. There is something very... pure about you and -- a little bit stupid. Or, no, it’s... a kind of innocence. You’re so -- unconscious. Yet. I can’t help it, I like you. I don’t blame you. I just shouldn’t have allowed him back in my life. I had decided against it, even in Canada. I wasn’t even going to let it happen. It was the snow. It was the cozy, cozy snow. Der Wassa Huchlich. We just... fell for each other again. I wanted my husband back.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t think you have to lose him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (with a flash of anger) You know what? If he does call you, tell him to screw off. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell him from me.(Seeing Justine enter) Hello darling!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How about if I take all the kids for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Stop it. Stop trying to take care of everybody.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It's fine. They won’t mind, they’re used to me, right Justine?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: Could you please just tell me what’s going on? Both women look at the child. She stares back at them solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Your Dad and I had a big fight and he’s taking some time.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: (to Georgette) Are you and him getting back together?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: It’s a complex situation. Justine: a disturbing thought is forming. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) Are you sad?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Angry? Justine looks at the women for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: You guys really have no idea what you're doing, do you? Maggie and Georgette stand unable to answer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, there is no plan, is there?

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MINIVAN / QUEENS STREETS
dialogues.text: Maggie is driving Georgette, Justine, Paul, and Lily back QUEENS. She looks dolefully at Georgette in the passenger seat. Georgette is staring, catatonic. Now Maggie will be taking care of her, too. INT. QUEENS LOFT - JUSTINE’S ROOM / KITCHEN - NEXT DAY 98 School time! Maggie tiptoes down the hall and peeks into Justine’s room and sees Georgette asleep on an air mattre clutching John’s manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Justine did you find your charger?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Yes. Justine exits her room as:

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (yelling from kitchen) Where is my science book?!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sshshsh! Maggie runs into kitchen, picks up Lily and puts her on h hip. Packing snacks, book bags, pencil cases, her own bri case, making oatmeal... the kitchen is a mess. Georgette stalks into the room carrying John’s manuscript

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Maybe two hours.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Go back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I’ll help, then go back later. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Really.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I want to help. Georgette, determined to help, squints to see the print o the dish washing liquid, then shrugs and puts some in the dishwasher, turns it on, then sits on the couch and start reading again. She’s almost done.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Justine) What about your basketball uniform? I washed it--

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s okay, it’s all folded, just -- here -- it’s almost quarter after, we're gonna be late if --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can’t find any socks.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Just take some out of the laundry basket.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (yelling from the other room) They're dirty!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Wear them anyway, it’s fine. (to Justine) You have your pencil case? Maggie grabs a canvas shopping bag and stuffs the gear in it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay let’s go! Paul is looking at something.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maggie...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maggie turns. There are suds foaming out of the dishwashe lot of suds. Maggie runs toward the suds and dives in to the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie, a few residual suds in her hair, shepherds everyo into the car and leaves. Lily shouts out numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgette finishes the book, closes it, contemplates it furiously. She then gets up, takes a metal trash can, put on the coffee table, and lights the first page of the manuscript. It goes up in flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie’s van chugs along on the way in to Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie runs into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgette sets another page of John’s manuscript alight. merry fire leaps up. Georgette watches it burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie runs out of work at the end of the day. Still late

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie walks in, breathless, overwrought, Lily on one hip groceries on the other.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Twenny five - twenny seven! Fitty two! Justine and Paul tumble in behind her. Georgette is showe and dressed. She seems more collected. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hi! Georgette takes the bag of groceries. Maggie puts Lily do and Lily runs to her corner to play. Maggie sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is something burning?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m thinking steamed carrots and pork chops.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I’1ll make apple sauce. Georgette peels an apple. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) Thank God it’s Friday.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I think if we take them all skating tomorrow, then you go to the movie with Justine. It’ll scare Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No it won't!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Yes it will.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: It’s rated PG-13 Paul. You can only handle G.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s not fair.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: I’m not having you crawling in my bed for the next month.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Paul) I can take you and Lily to something else. Let’s look at what’s playing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is “Ice Maiden Adorable” still playing?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You really want to see that again?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes! Justine makes a retching face as she gets a snack from th fridge.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: We can’t do that to Maggie. That’s not fair.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t care, I’1ll take a nap. Maggie has started chopping carrots.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ow! Maggie’s nicked her finger and sucks the tip.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Maggie. Sit down. Where are the band-aids? Maggie points to a shelf, sits. Georgette gets her a band and puts it on Maggie’s trembling finger. Maggie is panicking.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Georgette) Have you heard from John?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: I did. He sold his car and bought a motorcycle. And he’s taking us to the Giants on Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Oh for God’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Where is he living?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: I’1l ask him when we’re in the stands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Georgette turns to Maggie, who is on the verge of a panic attack. She can’t breathe well and she’s almost in tears.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Justine can you take Paul in to watch TV? Justine and Paul go.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m sure if you see each other--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: No more matchmaking ideas. No more ideas, period. You’ve had your thinking license revoked.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I‘ll never get involved with anyone else’s fate again -- not even my own. I’1l become a completely passive, non-interventional -- Buddhist. I just feel like you guys were so close to--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You have to let this go, Maggie. This story has its own momentum, apart from you. It always did.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. I thought I was going to do something really grand, like a coup... I’m so sick of being me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You should really try the tapping.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What tapping?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I went to a workshop on biofeedback. It’s amazing. What you do is, you figure out the essential thing you want to change, and you make a sort of dictum. Like, for you, “I am not controlling,” maybe. Or whatever you want to change. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: ‘I am not controlling’ is good.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: And you tap like this-- Georgette taps herself on the top of the head, between th eyebrows, under her nose, on her chin, her temple, behind ear, and on the wrist, and Maggie imitates her, repeating after her, emotion building in her still and brimming ove she taps. GEORGETTE (CONT’D) I am not controlling. (tap tap tap)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I am not controlling. (tap tap tap)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: (tapping) I leave people to their own fate.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (tapping) I leave people to their own fate. Etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgette marches toward camera with great determination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgette waits, a coffee beside her. John sets his helme the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So why did you want to see me? He sits. They glare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I wanted to return your book. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She takes a plastic baggie filled with ashes from her pur and puts it in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where shall I scatter these?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Anywhere is fine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you burned my fucking book, on top of everything else.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I burned a copy of your book.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You probably didn’t even read it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Of course I read it. That’s why I burned it! You cannibalized our marriage to write that story.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You didn’t even bother to fictionalize us in yours.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t write fiction!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You think you painted a precise portrait of us in “Bring Back the Geisha?” I can’t believe you're making me feel bad about the sins of my unpublished novel -- are we just going to gloss over your actual lies and manipulation?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I’m not a liar! You know I never lie. I lied now... I manipulated... I debased myself morally -- because... I loved you so terribly much. Maybe you could be flattered. This reaches him a little. He knows what it costs her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: If you love me so much, why not just -- tell me?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: You were married.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, Georgette.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: So you won’t take any responsibility for the state of your life? You’re just a victim of our plot?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m not a victim. I’m just a man who has fucked his life up and is now trying to find an airbnb to live in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: There is nothing more to say in that case. She starts putting on her coat; he makes ready to go. It’ over. Then, she stops. She’s making one more tactical military maneuver to conquer him: He stares GEORGETTE (CONT’D) The reason your novel doesn’t work is: You put too much weight on the allegory. You're trying to use fiction to prove a thesis. The text is crying out for passages of pure economic theory. Narrative blended with theory is your specialty. Make it into a John Harding book and it could be a phenomenon.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I know it John. You just have to accept it’1ll probably be published by Yale University Press, not Scribner's. Mark my words: you'll be shortlisted for a Bateson Prize. You might even get one. at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Fuck. You did it again.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You know me better than I know me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish I didn’t. He really sees her. The air is charged.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You look very beautiful in that light.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: I‘1l seek out these lighting conditions whenever possible in that case.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You do that. He moves toward her. And then, they kiss, ravenously...
105 106 Maggie wakes up from an unremembered dream, filled with a glorious intuition. Lily sleeps beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is dressing Lily. They talk and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and Lily skate on the ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily and Maggie brush their teeth in their pyjamas.  109 112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day. Maggie and Lily play on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and Lily eat their eggs. A sense of contentment. Absolute love. EXT -— PROSPECT PARK - ICE RINK - DAY 111 Three weeks later. One shot: Lily is skating between Magg and John, each holding a little hand. She is wearing a pi that says “I’m Three!” on it. Maggie and John hand Lily t skating instructor, flanked by Justine. The instructor escorts Lily to a clutch of little girls on skates.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRLS
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, Lily! This is Lily's third birthday party. It’s a skating party The skating instructor calls out cheerful commands. We fo John as he skates over to Georgette, who is holding onto railing for dear life. She loses her balance. John catche her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Winter sports aren’t really your strong suit.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGETTE
dialogues.text: It’s not fair! On skates I’m not able to defend myself.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'm keeping you on ice for the rest of your life, in that case. He pushes her on the ice as she screams in fear and joy. the stands, Tony, Felicia, and Max watch this tender scen Tony is lacing up Max’s skates. Maggie skates up to them leans on the barrier.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (referring to Georgette and John) Has it ever occurred to you that this might have all happened anyway? Even if you hadn’t played Titania and sprinkled fairy dust in everyone’s eyes? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Of course it’s occurred to me.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: You'll never know if it was you, or the Hand of Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I've decided to embrace the mystery of the universe and stop bossing everyone around so much.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Good luck with that, bossy pants. Max walks off, toward the ice. Maggie stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He’s been listening to us this whole time? Max is already walking to the skating rink.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: One day he’s going to write a book about us all. And we are not going to look good. Max skates off--he’s a demon skater. Felicia watches Lily skate by in the gaggle of little girls.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (shouting, to Justine) ...fifty-two a hundred!, fifty- three a hundred!, fifty-four...

dialogues.speaker: FELICIA
dialogues.text: What kind of three year old loves numbers that much?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Was John good at math? Because you certainly weren't.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure... Something is dawning on Felicia, and then it dawns on Ton But Maggie is skating away already. Maggie backs up on the ice, alone, happy. Stay with her a moment. She’s a good skater. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then, she sees: walking over the crest of a hill, making way toward the rink, skates slung over his broad shoulder is Guy. The pickle entrepreneur. Who skates every Sunday. Glowing with idiosyncratic appeal. Backing up, Maggie sta at him in surprise, then thoughtfulness, then affection. backs up till she hits the barrier of the rink. She can’t back up anymore. Move closer and closer to her watching G until she is in a huge close up, on the very edge of her move.
